qas.question: Who helped The Encyclopedie find its way into print using the French censorship law creatively?
The King and Clement XII condemned which literary work?
What percentage of books borrowed in England, Germany, and Norath America were novels?
What percentage of books borrowed were of a religious nature in England, Germany, and North America?

context: A healthy, and legal, publishing industry existed throughout Europe, although established publishers and book sellers occasionally ran afoul of the law. <a1_0>The Encyclopédie<a1_0/>, for example, condemned not only by the King but also by Clement XII, nevertheless found its way into print with the help of the aforementioned <a0_0>Malesherbes<a0_0/> and creative use of French censorship law. But many works were sold without running into any legal trouble at all. Borrowing records from libraries in England, Germany and North America indicate that more than <a2_0>70<a2_0/> percent of books borrowed were novels. Less than <a3_0>1<a3_0/> percent of the books were of a religious nature, indicating the general trend of declining religiosity.
